posts.title: Zanzibar Mix
posts.markdown:
Ancient Omani history, a Portuguese legacy, modern Swahili culture and a melting pot of Islamic beliefs meet in the humid, winding gullies of Zanzibar Island’s Stonetown. Bikes ring bells constantly and weave around those on foot, coconut water (madafu) sunbathes on sidewalks, and fresh cut mangos with chilies are the refreshing snack of choice.

Foodies would find the choices here surprising and adventurous. I met Shariffa in a small dark room with exposed coral walls and only two benches pushed roughly to one corner for customers. She massages dal bhajias (lentils) quickly and expertly into neat round balls and tosses them into a vat of oil.

Her food is cooked on a coal stove. Three women in Islamic dress are enjoying a bowl of the famous mix and nod in encouragement as I ask about the famous food. My tour guide Salim orders the mix and we sit outside on a step in the street and chat about the extraordinary amount of cats wandering about. Apparently the Omanis treasured the dozens of cats they had as a status symbol in the aristocratic homes. They had to leave in a hurry when they came under attack and left their four legged creatures behind. The cats multiplied and roam the town even today.

Ten minutes later I dive into the dal bhajia that sits in a mango pulp mixture, shaved cassava, boiled potatoes and delicious coconut chutney. The recipe maximizes on the availability and flavor of easily available local food ingredients on the island. It’s remarkably fresh. It’s spicy and sweet. For those with steely stomachs, I recommend it. Shariffa’s is one of the most popular places in Stonetown and she does a roaring business. She’s not interested in expanding it, she says, she has a roof over her head and can put food on the table. No franchises here.

posts.title: The Mama and I
posts.markdown:
Well, it's time to get this party started once again this semester…I’m sitting in disbelief at the amount of stuff I have due next week. I thought this was my final semester in b-school, what’s all this work coming at me about? Someone must have been smoking the green stuff when they claimed this would be an easy semester, because it is pretty evident that my professors are intent on making my behind work like an animal this semester.I’m still going to Brazil and Argentina, that’s for real (ended up having a ball in South America). I don’t care if I have a midterm the day after spring break.

So it seems a lot has happened while we all took off and did the do during the holidays (wrote this right after the elections). Now, we have an MBA as the president of the country. I’m not necessarily jumping up for joy, I mean, this puts the MBA crowd in the spotlight and it doesn’t make it any better that he’s from Harvard. We all know their work ethic, so if Dubya blows the economy or screws up the country’s fiscal policy, then MBA recruiters are going to start re-evaluating their relationships with business schools. Now, if he was a Stern MBA, with a couple of courses with Messrs. Smith and Yermack, then I would feel a lot more confident (ok, so it gets a little competitive amongst b-schools, that's why MBAs are such a sorry bunch). We’ll watch and see, G.W. Don’t go starting a war with Hawaii (yes it is one of the 50 states, Dubya) or Puerto Rico when stuff hits the fan, you better dig into your “Conflicts and Negotiations” textbook and handle your business, boy (wow, it's almost like I knew this bobo would start something...damn!!).

So I had an interesting vacation. I’m sitting at home, watching TV when I got a phone call from my mother in Nigeria . We talked for a little bit, y’know, I missed her, she missed me, my grandfather (Pimp Daddy Extraordinaire) was married (he's about 95 years old...I want to be like him when I grow up. Pimp Daddy!!)…y’know, the good stuff.

Then she got silent.“Mama,” I inquired, “are you alright?” Now, in most African cultures, once your parents or elders take a long pause (the pauses have gradually increased as the wedding day gets nearer) when they are speaking to you, your ass is about to get toasted. Dunked on. Plastered. I heard her exhale on the other end. “Chidi, my son,” she started. My heart did a triple axle-trifecta-double-pumped somersault. I popped two Levitra...sorry, two Tylenol extra strength in anticipation of the migraines headed my way via the phone line.

She continued, “I am proud of you. I am really proud of you. You are about to graduate with an MBA and you are the envy of many of your friends back home in Nigeria (actually, no envy whatsoever. The fact is, I didn't become a doctor. That signals failure. If you are a young Nigerian in the States and you are not a doctor or pharmacist, you have failed the Igbo Nation. You are required to denounce you Igbohood sixty days after failure). You have done well and God has blessed me with a first son like you.” She paused again.

Oh, boy.

Okay, now let me explain what she was doing here. This was a common technique used by our folks when serious topics where discussed. Let me use an anecdote to break it own for you. I attended boarding school in Nigeria. It was the best experience in my life; it was also the most harrowing six years any young man could live through on this planet (high school in Nigeria was just incredible. I have the scars to prove it). Oz? That is Disney World compared to boarding school in Nigeria. Anyways, when I was about fifteen, in Class 5 (which is equivalent to the junior year in high school), we had an occurrence of rat attacks. Yes, rat attacks. Fellas would wake up in the morning and discover parts of their toes missing. You would be sleeping in your corner and then get jolted awake by the piercing scream of some poor sonofabitch, whose pinkie toe was now half there, half gone. At first we thought that the spirits of Rumuokwuta were finally exacting justice upon the poor pinkie-less souls, but we had to investigate.

A nocturnal investigative team was formed to find out what was going on. I ran point on the team. What we saw shocked even myself, who had connections with the spirit world (we still talk, but we had a falling out. always scaring me half to death). At approximately ten to fifteen minutes after two in the morning, as we regaled each other with tales from the crypt, these humongous rats would come out of the woodworks, sneak into the dorm room and position themselves right at the juiciest feet on the lower bunk beds. Then they would nibble a bit on the toe, then blow softly on the toe to intercept and obliterate any pain signals going to the poor guy’s brain. Nibble, blow, nibble, blow (i swear!!). The poor guy wouldn’t feel a thing.

You see, I was getting the “nibble, blow” treatment from The Mama.

“So, my son. I need to ask you a question.” I popped two more Tylenols.

“When are you going to get married?”

Whoa. (yeah...like whoa!)

The Mama started tearing into me. “All your friends here in Nigeria have gotten married (every single one of them). I went to Okey’s wedding last week. In fact, Kelechi is about to have her second baby.”

I was speechless. Kelechi? Her second baby? Damn. She was fine, too. Now that’s someone I could have married (thank God I didn't. I heard she went psycho on her husband, and got a job).

“Well…uh…Mama…y’see…” I was stuttering like a Stern MBA at a Bain interview.

“Don’t you ‘well…uh’ me. Look, you are old enough to father as many children as the head cockerel on our compound (true, true). Tell me, Chidi, what are you waiting for, eh?” (uh, graduation? A job? Some money? How about a woman?) The Mama was getting heated and I was not helping by cowering on the other end of the line. I had to mount a strong defense.

“But, Mama,” I countered, “I am going to school. I have no money, I don’t even have a job, what woman would want a broke man like me. I can’t even buy water.” Now, that was a good counter-attack.

“Shaaarrraaappp, you idiot”, The Mama bellowed into the phone. “What do you mean you are broke, eh? Didn’t you tell me some of your classmates are being offered salaries of two hundred thousand dollars a year? (ok...so maybe I exagerrated a little bit there). I have told everyone you will be making at least three hundred thousand since you are smarter than all of them, right? (now this is bordering on delusional). Didn’t you tell me you already had an offer? ”

Typical Naija. Four rapid fire sentences, and they all ended with question marks.

Damn. I fed her all that stuff so she could feel like this MBA thing was a good idea. Now she was using it against me. And there was no way I was going to start explaining that the economy was “receding” some of those freaking gazillion, pravillion dollar offers. My mother is brilliant. I never could beat her in an argument, and I usually don’t lose my arguments (well, since The Ngozi showed up, I have been losing consistently every day).

She shoved aside the money issue. “I know you will make money, that is not a concern for me. I think it is time for you to get married and have children. Some of my friends have seen your pictures from America and they have come to visit me with their daughters.” She stopped to hear my reaction. I inhaled deeply. I knew this was bound to happen soon, so I pretty much acquiesced and asked her what she wanted me to do. I heard the rustling of paper on her end. The Mama always had her stuff together.

“Well, I have five girls that I really like. Their families are very well respected and these girls were raised very properly.” I could hear her smiling (i admit, I was smiling too).

“These girls are beautiful too. Do you remember Nkiru?” Yes, I remembered Nkiru. She dumped me like used toilet paper when I was sixteen. Now she wanted to marry me. I’m sure the picture of me beside my ex-boss’s Escalade XLT had nothing do with her sudden affection for me.

As I listened to her, I couldn’t help but note how absurd it all sounded. Who told her I wanted someone who was raised properly? Why couldn’t I get one of those booty-shaking girls in all those hip-hop videos (you know, I did end up with a booty shaking girl...heh-heh. Sorry, the Ngozi)?

The Mama then finished with one of her patented concluding statements. “Why don’t you come home in May and visit me? And you can also meet these girls, you might like one of them. I also have some presents that I have bought for you…actually, my friends bought them for you. Chidi, you know I love you, right?“

Nibble, blow, nibble, blow.

posts.title: The Lagos Tech Scene
posts.markdown:
mashable asks "is lagos home to an african tech movement?"

yes. it is.

let me break it down for you.

it's all about mobile and nigeria is a mobile haven, with most individuals rolling with at least two mobile phones from one or more of the incumbent carriers. estimates are that there were over 110m active mobile subscriptions in nigeria, by fall of 2012, compared to under 474k fixed lines. mobile penetration is hovering around 65% for a population of over 160 million people, according to world bank estimates.

the startup scene is hot. there is konga, that has aspirations to be the amazon of africa. the online megastore was founded by sim shagaya, former head of google africa.

not to be outdone, jumia, another online retailer and subsidiary of german incubator rocket internet, erected a 12,000 square foot warehouse in lagos in 2012.

wakanow is former nba and maryland center obinna ekezie's online travel website that is doing brisk business for travellers in sub-saharan africa.

if you haven't watched a nollywood (nigeria's booming movie industry) movie, then irokotv is your digital destination to catch up on your flicks. part netflix, part imdb, irokotv's jason njoku has cornered the market for nollywood svod. replace three letters in irokotv and you have ibakatv, which is also a nollywood online viewing destination.

of course, money transfer startups are sprouting up in this cash based economy. paga has captured the lead for mobile payments and transfers in nigeria.

looking for a gig in nigeria - jobberman has your back.

need to buy a ride? check out cheki nigeria.

the big names have all landed in lagos. microsoft is active in the dev community. google nigeria provides its potent suite of online platforms and apps to businesses and celebrities, including google trader. there is a brand new apple istore, opened in dec '12. blackberry and nokia compete for mobile device domination in the nigerian market.

co creation hub nigeria or, cchub as it is more well known as, is a primary focal point, pre-incubation and gathering spot for the tech community in lagos.

even the tech blogging scene in naija is blossoming nicely with outfits such as techloy, otekbits, and tech360.

the nigerian tech scene is happening. and lagos is at the heart of it all.

so, yes, lagos is home to a burgeoning african tech scene. get on board.

posts.title: Why Do We Still Need the Constitution?
posts.markdown:
The Constitution is the defining document of our country’s government. Since its inception in 1787, the Constitution has molded the fabric of our nation’s governing policies. But in the face of growing partisanship and an increased inability to reach a consensus on basic ideals, critics question if the Constitution is still the best way to govern the United States.

Our Government under the Constitution

The Constitution outlines the principles with which to govern our country.

The first ten amendments, known as the Bill of Rights, gives Americans various rights including protection against self-incrimination and the right to bear arms. Even the process of checks and balances, presidential term limitations, and women’s voting rights are covered in this historic document.

Why the Constitution should remain

Proponents of the governance by the Constitution say the country runs efficiently under the Constitution. Why change what works? In addition to providing rights and privileges to Americans, Constitutional amendments have adapted to issues facing our modern society. There have been 27 amendments to the Constitution since its inception; which have addressed specific issues facing the country at the time. For example the 13th Amendment was included to abolish slavery in the 1860s and the 19th gave women the right to vote. These amendments are indications that the Constitution can be kept current and relevant to changing times and paradigms.

The Constitution has also made it possible to keep all branches of the government in check. Without it, the executive branch or event the legislative branch of the government would have unlimited powers and would undermine the very definition of democracy. In essence, proponents say the Constitution safeguards American democracy.

Has the Constitution kept up with the times?

However, critics against the Constitution have been equally vocal. They see it as an outdated document and question the effectiveness of something that was written hundreds of years ago. In a New York Times Op-Ed article, Georgetown professor Mike Seidman even questions why we would loyally follow a document written by men that believed women had no place in government and that it was appropriate to own other humans. There have also many arguments against the Constitution’s views on gun ownership. When the Second Amendment was added to the Constitution in 1791, the United States was a new country and just barely out of the war with England. The initial purpose of the amendment was to offer Americans the opportunity to protect their homes and states in the chance of another war. Our founding fathers could not foresee the advances in technology in weaponry and the amount of destruction that could be caused by guns. Critics of the Constitution claim this is yet another sign that the document is outdated and out of touch.

There have also many debates about completely doing away with the Constitution. But would it be possible or even advantageous to do this? Opponents argue that Americans should follow amendments like freedom of speech and religion out of respect. However, updating or doing away with controversial amendments like the 2nd Amendment (The right to bear arms) would be much harder due to political polarization.

In fact, political polarization is so strong in this country that making any amendments to the Constitution is incredibly difficult. There have been over 11,000 attempts to amend the Constitution but only 27 have been successful. In this case, political polarization may be too difficult to overcome.

Do you think the Constitution is still relevant? Should there be a major overhaul? Do you think the parties could come together to make a significant change?

posts.title: The Survival Kit
posts.markdown:
We were all laughing at the young lady behind us. She was clutching for, pretty much anything. Her seat, the seat in front of her, the seat behind her including the people in those seats. She was probably saying her final prayers. “If I survive this I will become a nun, please Lord”. The other lady next to me kept explaining with a heavy Danish accent that they were warned about our (in)famous Matatus. Unfortunately for them the driver was having a 'party of the lanes' much to her disgust. “This is very different from Odense”, she insisted.

For those of us who are used to it, we will tell you that we have experienced a little bit of everything from our daily commutes. Near death experiences to ones that were more humorous than deadly, a run in with traffic police to meeting interesting people. I said meeting but I really meant staring. From fancy ones that have all kinds of graffiti, lights and loud music to the old has beens that need the tout to occasionally carry the door all by his lonesome. You cant escape using them. Anywhere you want to go, there is a matatu that will most likely get you there. They are the most used means of transport in Kenya.

For my all interaction with matatus, I have come to grow accustomed to all it's horseplay. To develop a level of tolerance I came up with a 'daily survival kit' for what to do when in a matatu. In all my commutes this kit has never failed me. Someone cc WikiHow.

Choose The Best Seat

If you can, because believe me you don't want to end up seated next to the lady that takes up her seat plus half of yours, has like five kids who wont stop crying and is carrying more luggages than she has hands. You will come out of the matatu with a certificate in fatherhood and luggage handling. So what is the best seat in the house you ask? The one behind the conductor. Its a single seat which means I don't have to deal with anyone more than myself. When you want to alight, you don't bother anyone and no one else bothers you when they are alighting. Perfect. I don't always get this seat but when I do, its one less thing to worry about.

Earphones

Listen, I don't advocate for asocial behavior, but if you've ever had a heated political debate with someone who had eggs and an onion inspired meal for breakfast at 7am on A MONDAY MORNING you will understand where I am coming from. You cant take that conversation back. Neither can you take his breathe away (Pun). Worse still you are sat where the window just wont budge open. Jesus didn't wash away my sins for this. Never forget your earphones.

A Sense of Humor.

Crazy things happen. They always do. They should set up a Matatus Anonymous. I imagine the stories that will come out would easily beat The Audacity of Hope to the Pulitzer. You need to have a sense of humor. Just yesterday, as I was headed home from the city center and everyone was doing their thing, we started hearing strange noises from the back of the matatu. It was so strange and loud that it caused quite a commotion. After a brief inquiry, a lot of debate and the driver actually having to pull over to the side of the road, we finally discovered that there was a goat at the back below the seats. It's owner quietly asleep as we scratched our heads. We had a good laugh!

I hope this helps some sorry soul out there!

posts.title: Welcome to aKoma
posts.markdown:
I believe in passion. I believe in purpose. I believe in following a dream fearlessly.

So I’ve created aKoma: stories made @ africa

It will start as a writing platform. Next we will do video and TV.

aKoma needs your voice. Your talent. No filter.

For many years I’ve wanted to create a media company that covers the diversity of Africa the way I believe it should be covered. aKoma is my first step.

I’m sick of the disaster, war, flies on faces, disease, refugee camps, and terror images of Africa. I’m sick of associating animals and beaches only with Africa.

You and I know there is more. So much more. We are one billion people, each of us with lifestyles and aspirations, those in other parts of Africa or the rest of the world know little or nothing about. Well, now they will.

aKoma means “heart.” That’s the only ingredient I want writers to have on this platform. Put your heart into your storyteller’s voice.

It can be personal, it can be a crazy idea, it can be as mundane or as moving a topic you want, as short or as long as you like. You can share pictures that grab you, or an image you sketch that captures something meaningful. You can share knowledge and pass on tips, and news you can use.

I want us to show that we are the land of innovation where the next big idea that will change the world, we have a vibrant lifestyle, an intellecual middle class, entrepreneurial spirit, a creative industry with talent that is mind blowing, our women are trail blazing and leading, we are connected. We have class.

We have problems too. Cool. We can talk about those openly. We are respectful of differences. We are sophisticated.

I would like to train, hire or inspire the best Africa focused storytellers who get the most hits and shares to be part of our team.

My team and I will work hard to bring you the audience you want and to showcase aKoma writers and thinkers. That is our responsibility, and we are going gangster.

I will share everything i’ve learned after fourteen years at CNN with you. You won’t need to spend money to buy the book ! I will transfer all my knowledge, and that of my friends and colleagues, to you on aKoma.

Many of you know I am from Kenya. My family has lived here for more than one hundred years. My great grandfather stood on the same platform as Jomo Kenyatta for independence, Kenya made my career, Kenyans and all Africans around the world have supported me all my life and inspired me to break glass ceilings.

Let's #inspireafrica. I’m so very proud and excited to introduce aKoma : stories made @ africa.

Karibuni. Welcome.

posts.title: Black Moor Survivors
posts.markdown:
The crunch of shattered glass beneath my feet, the bullet holes in windows and the acrid smell of disaster enveloped me the moment I entered my favorite mall in Nairobi. It was surreal. Days ago a massacre happened here as friends and family lived out a typical mundane errand and chatter filled Saturday morning.

I felt hollow, paralyzed as the magnitude of the inane bloodshed and violence that occurred lay on a fractured canvas before me. I was dazed. A lump in my throat fought back insistent tears as I recalled numerous coffees at Art Café, endless ice-cream purchases at Nakumatt, banking with dad upstairs or sharing a strawberry frozen yogurt downstairs.

That store was shot up, I could only imagine the terrified frenzy there, My CNN producer, Victoria Eastwood and I secretly started to film the scenes around us on our i-phones inside Westgate Mall. No media organization had been allowed to enter ground zero that lay between the Parklands and Westlands areas of the city. Chairs lay on the ground and a half finished coffee, signs that ended life in mid sentence.

We had posed as family members of one shop owner who was there to clear what was left of his store. One hour ago we snuck in with someone who recognized me at Nakumatt Ukay shopping center, and was going to check on his car, one of the few still left pristine and white on the parking deck roof.

For a long time, I stared at the most shocking space. The rooftop corner where children where learning how to cook before they were ruthlessly gunned down. Burned out remnants remained and I turned my eyes away, to look at the gaping hole on the imploded deck.

My father and I had walked through this space countless times looking at children play, shopping at the open-air market or validating our tickets and talking. I was as comfortable as Westgate as I am in my own home. It felt personal and it was hollow and horrifying.

Affluent Nairobi consists of a small circle and we all knew someone who was at the mall, missing from the mall, affected by the mall, hurt or dead.

In the horror and furor, Nairobi had risen to the occasion, just like its citizens did during the US embassy bombing, when I was there. Every community, every race, medical facilities, religious and political leaders pulled together. The least I could do was pull myself together and do the most professional, objective job I could, and apply only journalism, not emotion, to what I was articulating live on the air.

For days there were rumors about victims, about terrorists who had escaped, confusion over who had the upper hand terrorists or the security forces, was the mall booby trapped with explosives, was the army looting, where there hostages.

I’m not a war reporter. I never aspired towards it. Yet I found myself standing with a flack jacket, helmet and with gunshots ringing out, close to our live position, a Jain religious and cultural center called Oshwall, where grandmas and grandpas often come to walk around the track.

The advantage of being a local Kenyan was that I knew most people, the public knew me, and most importantly trusted me. This meant I was getting significantly more information than any other journalist, either local or international and I had to be very careful with it.

I was in communication with senior officials at State House, with the Kenyan intelligence agency, Rwandese intelligence, two British Intelligence contacts and a CIA source. The information I was getting was conflicting, terrifying, and fascinating all at the same time. Everyone at this moment is trying to figure out what is going on. What is real? What is reportable? Much information is unconfirmed or unauthorized for use. I didn’t want to terrify Nairobi, already on edge and in shock, and I didn’t want to report information that was either too sensitive or could be construed as rumor.

I almost hadn’t made it to Nairobi for this assignment. I had arrived at Oxford University on Saturday morning that September for the first residence of a Masters Degree in Creative Writing and was on vacation, determined nothing would take me away from the mandatory few days.

Walking back from Costa coffee, the wires started to cross.

‘Gunshots heard at Nairobi’s Westgate Mall.’

‘Eyewitnesses report casualties.’

‘Terrorists take hostages at Nairobi’s Westgate mall.’

My mouth went dry. My mum and dad often go to Westgate mall on a Saturday morning. I couldn’t get through for a while, and my shirt started to drench with panicked sweat. Oxford phone networks are mind-blowingly lousy and I ran back and forth on the street trying to get a signal, my hands shaking.

“We are OK” came a text from my father. I exhaled, and started to frantically type a guidance note to CNN editorial about Westgate Mall and what information I was starting to receive. The international desk brought me in for beepers, phone interviews, the rest of the afternoon.. Deborah Rayner, a senior CNN executive, called me and ordered me to cancel Oxford and get on the first plane to Nairobi.

I hadn’t seen the pictures of the siege for hours and was operating in a video vacuum and didn’t fully comprehend that magnitude of the situation until I arrived home. Before I packed up left amid tears, my father called. He had been on his way to Westgate that morning for an errand and decided that it would be too busy, so fortunately diverted his trip.

“Listen, Julie was in Westgate and made it out,” he said.

“What?” I responded, confused as to why he was telling me about my aunt, his older sister, who lives in London. He explained quickly that she and her husband Nizar were on holiday, and in the mall. They hid out, and hours later, made it out while terrorists were inside firing at close range.

“She’s fine but a bit shaken up,” he said.

“Send me her number please”, I asked realizing CNN would be able to use an articulate eyewitness account on the air. My aunt was tough and a survivor, she always has been.

I received many more eyewitness accounts while covering this story, in particular relating to the White Widow, British terrorist Samantha Leiwthwaite, believed to have been the mastermind behind this attack. There exists a photograph circulated among intelligence agencies that believe show her walking out of the mall, in plain sight, along with everyone else fleeing. No one has confirmed this on the record.

Victoria was an excellent producer who had both a strong editorial mind as well as a logistical and organizational calm under fire, which was stabilizing to any talent. We analyzed all intelligence coming to CNN and decided what was news worthy, what could be backed up, and what could not.

Victoria quickly came to believe the strength of my sources on the ground. I would receive a text.

“An explosion is about to happen”. Seconds later, it did.

“Wear your helmet and flack jacket. Terrorists believed on the loose in your area.” Gunfire erupted almost immediately.

In moments, I felt I was in a really bad action movie. Our family friend Collette, a spa manager and owner on Peponi Road close to the mall, gave the whole CNN team access to bathrooms, shelter from rain, and the use of her kitchen for our planning and analysis ‘war room’.

By now the team was much bigger, Nima el-Bagir and Arwa Damon were in town with their respective producers and Kim Norgaard arrived as ringmaster of the CNN coverage. Sometimes too much talent and egos battling to be on air can turn ugly, particularly if one reporter swoops down late in the game and ‘bigfoots’ the rest. But between the three of us, the dynamic was great as was the division of labor between the human toll story, newsgathering, and the investigation angle.

One of the women who died in the attack was a pregnant radio DJ. Victoria and I went to her funeral, in our private capacity. It was a Muslim funeral, at the Ismaili Mosque. Thousands of people had turned out to pay their respects. Everyone I met was in shock, trying to avoid looking at the tragic bump in her stomach, and processing terror close to home. Aria, our family hairdresser and friend, and her daughter Shivani were there and we were all moved to tears.

President Uhuru Kenyatta finally made a statement on TV that the siege was over. Minutes later I finished my last live, exhausted with no sleep for four days and walked to our van. The phone rang. It was State House, adding to information and clarifying details which Victoria and I wrote up and sent in to CNN wires.

After a strong drink, I finally drifted off to sleep for a few hours at a hotel in town. I vividly recall the image that night. I am sitting in a car leaving the crushed rooftop of Westgate one final time. In my hands are the only survivors that day from the mall. They are two Black Moor fish in a plastic bag filled urgently with water. They swim in circles, glancing at each other, eyewitnesses that will never tell.

posts.title: Rena
posts.markdown:
Rena

It was 1999 and I was hosting the mid morning show on Capital FM radio in Nairobi, anchoring the KTN news at night, and stringing for the BBC world service putting together more serious pieces. I had made a shift from entertainment only to hard news instantly when I saw the black smoke rise from the window on the nineteenth floor of Lohnro House in down town Nairobi on August 7, 1998.

The time was 10:38am. That was the moment the US embassy in Nairobi was attacked by terrorists. I was on the air. I remember how the building shook and how I thought it must be an earthquake. I remember watching a bearded American journalist for CNN reporting on the story a day later. His name was Jerrold Kessel. I never imagined I would one day be interviewing him on the air, as his anchor.

Months later at our home in Parklands, I was watching CNN one evening. I got it in my head “I can do that.” I tend to act quickly and relentlessly when I want something badly. Plus my dad always tells me to aim for the stars and even if I don’t make it, and land on the moon, then that’s OK too! So that’s what I did.

My friend Salim Amin of Camerapix in Nairobi referred me to a lady called Maggie Eales in London to whom I sent a demo tape of me reading the evening news at KTN. She passed in on to a woman who changed my life. Rena Golden, the head of talent and programming at CNN International based in London.

Once I received Rena’s email, I wouldn’t stop sending notes. The first time she emailed me, she told me that I looked good on camera but I had no real journalism experience and that I was more of an academic from what she could tell from my CV.

I responded saying that was not the case and I had done some very serious journalism for BBC radio. I offered to send her some scripts I had written under the guidance of senior producers in London. One of them was a thirty minute script on the deregistration of NGOs after the US embassy bombing in Kenya.

Rena agreed and I sent her every intelligent script I had written. She went silent for a long time and I mustered up the gall to send her another note. There were more that went by with no response.

At the same time I had been planning a trip to the United States to see a young man I was dating. In a breakthrough email to Rena, I said I was “coming to Atlanta anyway” and could she “please give me a screen test. “ My thinking was that I could use a piece of video with myself anchoring at CNN as part of another demo tape to send to another news organization. That was the best-case scenario for me professionally and personally I would have a wonderful time and spend a few days in Charleston and Savannah with my beau.

Rena replied saying something along these lines: “I am not hiring you, I will not give you a job, I will not pay for your ticket or your accommodation, but you can come if you want to and at your expense. I will give you a screen test.”

posts.title: A Tale of Two Grandmas
posts.markdown:
I believe in passion. I believe in purpose. I believe in following a dream fearlessly.

he year was 1974 and dusk had fallen in Kisumu, a town on the edge of lake victoria in Kenya. A family tragedy struck like a bolt of lighting. My grandfather Kassamali, and grandmother, Shirin, were entering their home at 8pm, returning from the mosque.

A lone guard, askari, stood in the parking lot adjacent to the entrance. Kassamali moved towards the guard asking what the matter was. The guard lunged towards him with a knife and stabbed him. Shirin had her hands slashed with a sharp blade, called a panga. She tried to help her husband but he bled to death. The killer was never found. The family believed it was motivated by a conflict over the Embassy Hotel Kassamali owned in Kisumu.

All five children of their children were devastated and the family fractured. The two sons fled to Canada, fearful they could be targeted in the dispute. My mother, Yasmin, the closest to my grandfather and the favorite, drove from Kisumu to Nairobi for the shocking funeral.

I had just been born that year, and never knew my grandfather, though I’m told he was a gentle and religious man. In a traditional Indian arranged marriage, he married my grandmother when she was twelve years old

She didn’t even have her period. Shirin had a tough life from an early age. She was poorly treated by her stepmother and equally mistreated by her mother-in-law. Shirin had five children and ran the household in Kisumu. When her husband started the struggle with his general store business and lost confidence, she stepped in and made deals with suppliers and structured the business and enabled the economic survival of her family.

After his death, she liquidated the businesses and left for Toronto, Canada. The funds she had asked a relative to remit, so she could survive in Canada, were never sent to her.

Shirin didn’t give up, and she was too proud to live off her sons. Her two married daughters were also in Toronto and she didn’t want to be a burden. She loved into a studio apartment alone, and got a job washing dishes in a hotel. She learned how to shop of groceries. She barely spoke English, and taught herself to do so over the years.

My Nanima (small mother, as we called our mother’s mother) learned how to take the bus and withstand brutally cold Canadian winters. Shirin became hardened, strong-minded, opinionated, and came to rely only on herself. Her joys were Indian movies, meditation and prayer, travel with her hard earned and saved money around the world with her group of grandmas, and her grandchildren who lived nearby.

Coming from an environment where house help and labor was plentiful, it was a massive cultural and social adjustment.

I lived with her for a few weeks, when I was in Canada attending McGill and York university. She gave me spending money, money for steroid medication for my skin disease, psoriasis when I didn’t have any, and didn’t get too angry with me when she found a packet of cigarettes hidden in my bag.

“This is not right,” she said, “it’s bad for your health”

“Please don’t tell mum,” was my desperate response.

“I won’t but stop it.”

She remained economically independent and strong willed until she passed away in 2009 in Toronto.

No matter how tough things got, she would say to all of us “Don’t worry, be happy,” somehow loving and internalizing the 1988 cappella hit song by Bobby McFerrin. This is how I remember her.

My dad’s mum, Daulat Khanu loved Boy George’s Karma Chameleon. I recall her dancing in a pink Indian Sari and singing with me at our old house in Gigiri, Nairobi.

“I’m amazed my one thing about you,” she said to me in Guajarati, the Indian dialect we spoke to both our grandmothers in.

“What?” I laughed dancing around, please that I just got the new ‘Now that’s what I called music’, cassette tape from London.

“That you can remember all the words to so many songs.” It’s true. I do have an uncanny memory for lyrics of songs I hear.

I was the closest of all grand children to Ma. I felt connected to her. She was a gentle spirit and cared for even the animals that lived around us.

She would feed sugar to the ants at home.

“What are you doing?” my father recalled asking her, startled at all the white lines in the garden.

“Even the ants have to eat,” she said, “who’s going to feed them.

She ordered prime meats for both Tommy the stray dog and mince for all the stray cats who I remember would turn up sharp at half past twelve for lunch daily.

Ma brought grocery items from old Kenyan women who would come to our gate with baskets of fresh vegetables and fruits.

She was born in a small town called Machakos in Kenya in 1920, the eldest of four children. Her family ran a laundry store in town and were relatively poor. She too had an arranged marriage to Remtuallah Verjee, my grandfather, a prominent man in Nairobi at the time.

She liked to dress both in Indian attire as well as English ladies dresses, with gloves and hats. She played rummy and bridge with friends on entertained a lot at home. Her life revolved around my grandfather and when he died in 1982, she lots her sense of purpose and joie de vivre, and suffered from depression and eventually a stroke.

I often think of Ma and Nanima and wonder what they would have thought of what I have done and become. I see Ma sitting near our grey old-fashioned telephone, on a dark brown chair, in a blue and white dressing gown, her hair in a bun, talking to her two close friends and laughing hard until her body shakes.

I see Nanima, cooking and softly singing to herself in her small cluttered apartment, watching the weather channel clock and making sure she was always on time.

My grandmothers combined taught me how to be tough, self reliant, to embrace Indian culture and at the same and to be gentle and compassionate in spirit.

posts.title: Corvus
posts.markdown:
Victory was lonely for detective Lucy Onyango.  The case breakthrough brought with it blinding flashlights, press conferences searching for a slick sound bite and a high profile award ceremony.  Her star status demanded she be there, the smart glamorous and powerful symbol for Kenyan justice.  But she was a no show for the dog and pony show. Every cellular device beeped and pinged her, until she removed the batteries to silence them. 

     She had earned this down time and no one was going to drag her out of the ritualized way she needed to spend it.  Not the Police Commissioner himself, not the media hounds, not her own sense of duty.  The vicious case was over and Lucy needed to self-inflict ‘pause’ and ‘mute’ while Nairobi churned ahead in a fast forward frenzy. 

     Alone in her darkened room, the drapes drawn, and windows pulled in, she tried to forget.  She remained numb for hours under the covers until it wore off and her demon, Feeling, returned. No matter how hard she attempted to block its surge, it rose like bile, her chest would ache, she would double over and the tears would gather to the edge of her lids but never cascade down her face.  The walls would witness only her silent screaming.  The self-imposed solitary confinement would last days, sometimes weeks.

     The moment she solved a case was naturally exhilarating and satisfying. But it was short-lived because her past always sabotaged her present. She would see history and bad choices thundering like a freight train in the night, carrying a cargo of blame, to hit her as she lay on railway tracks waiting for the headlines lights to inevitably come closer. Guilt and regret mingled in those moments, hate and pain that had been filed away years after it happened resurfaced, and Lucy couldn’t bear her self. “Mercy”, she whispered repeatedly.

     This case was particularly tough because young boys and girls had been the targets because they were white, too white. East African albinos in this region were coveted. Old wives tales that albino body parts held rare supernatural power were still believed, so dozens of children were kidnapped, trafficked between Kenya and Tanzania and killed.  Her informants had come through, the sting operation had been successful and Lucy had nailed the perpetrators.  They would face justice.

     Lucy lifted her tall sinewy body from her bed and stumbled out of the room, over her clothes, her gun, notebooks strewn on the floor, into the living room. She caught sight of herself in the mirror, exhausted red-rimmed eyes, her short hair stuck out in all directions exposing the small gold hoop earrings she had forgotten to remove.  She had thick lips and large almond shaped eyes, the color of which was onyx black and fierce, and could bore a hole into anyone during an interrogation.  Lucy stood in her white bra and underwear only.  Her tattoo on her back, between her shoulder blades, was visible, two diamond shapes, on their sides and clasped together, representing handcuffs for offenders of the law.  It was an old African folk symbol of law and justice.

     She was about to break it.  Lucy opened the sliding door of her flat in the South B area of Nairobi, and stepped onto the balcony, bending over to rummage inside a plant. She pulled out a clear plastic bag from the dirt.  What she did alone in her own space was her business, she just had to be careful or she would lose her position as the ranking female detective in the country, DCIO of Ongata Rongai police station.

     She would only turn to marijuana when she sank so deep into herself that she needed to block it all out. The flash of the body, in the ditch, another cut to pieces, the bleeding, the eyes, their lifelessness and their hopelessness in the last moments on earth.  Their loved ones would try to understand this level of brutality for the rest of their lives, wrestle with the courts, confront corruption, and incompetence.  It would destroy some, and breathe passion into others, championing causes, seeking change, perhaps even starting a foundation, yet none of that would ever fill the hole.  

     “Mercy,” she whispered as she lit up a tightly packed joint, closing her eyes, and throwing her head back in relief and allowing herself the cushion comfort of the smoke enveloping her. It was a relief. Thank goodness Alan, her boyfriend, was up country in Kiambu dealing with a sick aunt, and out of her way. He was a good man, he loved her, was loyal and rare. She didn’t know another Kenyan man who would be willing to do mundane household chores, and conduct a business on the sidelines. 

     Lately though, she had to push away a gnawing irritation with him.  It seemed unfair because he was loving and thoughtful.  He wanted their relationship formalized with his Kikuyu family and her Luo one, two opposing tribes.  Modern Kenya was fine with that, a Kariuki-Onyango marriage, but is that what she wanted? It seemed like the right, and natural step to take after two years.  Alan wanted a child soon, but she was resistant. She wasn’t sure she wanted to bring a child into the violent and hateful world she was immersed in.  Plus her new position was demanding, even with her unusual ability to recall sounds, images and small objects clearly.  An eidetic memory was what the doctor at Nairobi hospital had called it. Right now she was so foggy, she couldn’t remember.

posts.markdown:
I have spent more than a decade of my professional career on international television, my face visible to millions each day. Yet I have spent a lifetime hiding.

For years, I guard a painful secret: I can't bear to look in the mirror. I shrink from bright light. A gaze that lingers a second too long makes me panic. A hot summer day sends me into the shadows.

I have fish-like scales. There are tiny red islands floating on the surface of my skin. They combine to create continents with jagged surfaces. They turn black and start to smell. There is blood and pus.

My scalp spits out silver flakes. My ears are filled with crusts. I leave white specks wherever I sit. I float in long, loose clothes. My hands betray me. The sores sit openly. My nails are dented with pockmarks. I find strands of hair on the sheets and pillowcases every morning.

I suffer from psoriasis. It's ravaged my body since I was 8. At its worst my plaques look like leprosy. I feel like a leper.

"Please can you leave the pool," a woman once told me when I was 22, visiting the Dead Sea in Israel, "we're not comfortable with you in it." She is horrified at my body. I am ashamed. I hang my head.

The landscape from my neck down is chaos.

So I choose to look away. I am able to dress perfectly in the dark. I can feel my way around a room or a closet full of clothes. I instinctively choose the dimmest corner of a restaurant to sit in. Winters are a relief only because I won't stand out covered from top to toe.

My face is flawless. Not a blemish. Not a mark. Compliments are endless. But I am acutely aware that a horror film unfolds in secret beneath my clothes. I am effervescent and radiant on the outside and rotting inside. Which is the real me?

The cameras fire up, the red light turns on. I am splendidly made up. I lose myself in the moment. I am energized. I am focused. It's only my face. It is floating. It's all that exists. It gives me confidence.

No one has it all. I fight my body and myself all my life. I hit rock bottom many times because of my disease. It seems futile to try anymore. "Who will ever want me like this" I cry hysterically at home. "No one could ever touch me." My mother pulls me out self-loathing and defeatism. When I want to give up, she will not let me.

She becomes an expert on psoriasis. She reads medical journals and approaches alternative healers. She takes me for acupuncture and hypnosis. She mixes various acids in a lab for me to use on my skin and soaks me in a tub full of Dead Sea salt. The rest of the day, I am in a messy, smelly cream. Endless personal research, trial and error bring occasional relief.

Imagine the nightmarish teen years. I cower from close friendships. No one can know the truth. I never date. Intimacy is out of the question. I have no sensation of touch. The scales are too thick.

The itch is unbearable. I try and ignore it. It's impossible. It agitates me. I use all my strength and I tear at my skin. I am violent. I scratch back and forth until there is blood. It is too raw to do any more. I am filled with rage and humiliated.

So I disappear in my head, create fictional stories and characters. I play out entire conversations, lives and deaths, stories of courage and cowardice to escape myself. My mind is living a separate life from the body beneath it.

Somehow, my imagination takes me far. I am in my early 20s, and it's the beginning of my career. I am anchoring the prime time shows in Kenya. Tonight is a big opportunity. My game face is on.

I've spent the afternoon on hair and makeup. As I settle into the anchor's chair, I hear the faint rustle of plastic shrink wrap. I have wrapped up my legs and torso in the clingy film after soaking my scales in Vaseline so that the pain is lessened and the putrid smell contained. The director calls out. The floor manager cues me. The lights on, news copy in my hands, I smile and welcome millions of Kenyans into the studio.

The contrast is sharp -- behind closed doors, I have given up. I am on the floor. I am crying, screaming and itching insanely. My mother cries. I rarely see her cry. The last time was when my grandfather died.

Then an angel arrives.

A family friend approaches mum. "Your daughter looks unwell. She is losing her hair. What is the matter?" My mother, at her wits end, tells the woman the truth. "George," the angel says. "Tell her to go to George."

George is a small town in South Africa. I learn there is a clinic that specializes in treating severe skin disease. I adamantly refuse. I have had enough of doctors, hospitals, foul smelling topical creams and hopes dashed. Mum convinces me.

In a week, I find myself there against my wishes. I withstand the indignity, once again, of being naked, the grotesque lesions under neon light, and I listen to the shocked gasps of the doctors and nurses.

"We've never seen it this bad," one says in the tiny examination room.

I glance dully outside the window of my room to see a blue lake and a blue sky amid green trees and grass. Postcard perfect. I count the hours.

Who could imagine where I am? I am a celebrity in Nairobi, making it big.

"What do you do?" I am asked.

"Nothing," I respond curtly to any one who dares make conversation with me. I certainly don't want to start a conversation about being on television or hosting a radio show for that matter. What would my viewers on KTN and listeners on Capital FM Radio think of me?

Mind, body and spirit are the focus at this clinic. It sounds insane to me. I am told to do mediation, deep relaxation and creative visualization three times a day. I lie on the floor listening to the voice in charge.

"Every day in every way I am getting better and better. I have no desire to eat the foods I know are bad for me..." I brainwash myself. It works.

I eat yogurt or bran for breakfast, salads or fish for lunch and chicken for dinner. Nothing tastes good. I yearn for Tabasco. I drink only herbal tea and torrents of water.

I write a long letter to my psoriasis, describing how it causes me pain, how it hurts my relationships, how it makes me weak. I blame it for not allowing me to be free. I blame it for my rage, my violence, my bullying and my inability to feel loved, for my need for praise and constant reassurance.

I berate and belittle it. I coax and cajole it. I remind it of my sexless life. I beg and plead for it to go away. Then I thank my psoriasis. It has taught me to have no vanity, more compassion and to withhold judgment.

I am crying, emotionally drained, and hot underneath my long sleeves and jeans. I take a shovel, pick a spot outside and dig deep. I place the pages into the hole. I plant a tree. I use my hands to touch the earth. Nature seems surprisingly reassuring.

In this instance, I bury my past. I have said everything I needed to say to my skin. The tree will give life, oxygen. Perhaps it will give me a chance to breathe again.

A breakthrough.

It has been two weeks, and I see something no one else can see -- a tiny shift. In the center of one thick plaque, there is a slight thinning. I can discern this little dent only because I have been touching my skin.

This small success galvanizes me to stick rigidly to the tough diet I have promised to undertake.

I am ecstatic, fully of new energy. My smile is real. I am positive.

I return to Nairobi with a new mindset, a sense of control. I maintain the regimen like a military staff sergeant.

Every 28 days, I see progress. It is small. But it is there. The months pass. The smell stops. The centers of the lesions disappear like small mountains collapsing on themselves. They turn from red to pink to white.

I watch with fascination the metamorphosis of my skin. The continents on my body move apart with the seismic change in my mind. The scales no longer build. Then they are gone. I can't believe it.

It has been six months. I am clear. I am in remission. I have no scales. I am normal. I am finally free.

And there is no medication. Only food. "Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food."

I have fish-like scales. There are tiny red islands floating on the surface of my skin. They combine to create continents with jagged surfaces. They turn black and start to smell. There is blood and pus.

My scalp spits out silver flakes. My ears are filled with crusts. I leave white specks wherever I sit. I float in long, loose clothes. My hands betray me. The sores sit openly. My nails are dented with pockmarks. I find strands of hair on the sheets and pillowcases every morning.

I suffer from psoriasis. It's ravaged my body since I was 8. At its worst my plaques look like leprosy. I feel like a leper.

"Please can you leave the pool," a woman once told me when I was 22, visiting the Dead Sea in Israel, "we're not comfortable with you in it." She is horrified at my body. I am ashamed. I hang my head.

The landscape from my neck down is chaos.

So I choose to look away. I am able to dress perfectly in the dark. I can feel my way around a room or a closet full of clothes. I instinctively choose the dimmest corner of a restaurant to sit in. Winters are a relief only because I won't stand out covered from top to toe.

My face is flawless. Not a blemish. Not a mark. Compliments are endless. But I am acutely aware that a horror film unfolds in secret beneath my clothes. I am effervescent and radiant on the outside and rotting inside. Which is the real me?

The cameras fire up, the red light turns on. I am splendidly made up. I lose myself in the moment. I am energized. I am focused. It's only my face. It is floating. It's all that exists. It gives me confidence.

No one has it all. I fight my body and myself all my life. I hit rock bottom many times because of my disease. It seems futile to try anymore. "Who will ever want me like this" I cry hysterically at home. "No one could ever touch me." My mother pulls me out self-loathing and defeatism. When I want to give up, she will not let me.

She becomes an expert on psoriasis. She reads medical journals and approaches alternative healers. She takes me for acupuncture and hypnosis. She mixes various acids in a lab for me to use on my skin and soaks me in a tub full of Dead Sea salt. The rest of the day, I am in a messy, smelly cream. Endless personal research, trial and error bring occasional relief.

Imagine the nightmarish teen years. I cower from close friendships. No one can know the truth. I never date. Intimacy is out of the question. I have no sensation of touch. The scales are too thick.

The itch is unbearable. I try and ignore it. It's impossible. It agitates me. I use all my strength and I tear at my skin. I am violent. I scratch back and forth until there is blood. It is too raw to do any more. I am filled with rage and humiliated.

So I disappear in my head, create fictional stories and characters. I play out entire conversations, lives and deaths, stories of courage and cowardice to escape myself. My mind is living a separate life from the body beneath it.

Somehow, my imagination takes me far. I am in my early 20s, and it's the beginning of my career. I am anchoring the prime time shows in Kenya. Tonight is a big opportunity. My game face is on.

I've spent the afternoon on hair and makeup. As I settle into the anchor's chair, I hear the faint rustle of plastic shrink wrap. I have wrapped up my legs and torso in the clingy film after soaking my scales in Vaseline so that the pain is lessened and the putrid smell contained. The director calls out. The floor manager cues me. The lights on, news copy in my hands, I smile and welcome millions of Kenyans into the studio.

The contrast is sharp -- behind closed doors, I have given up. I am on the floor. I am crying, screaming and itching insanely. My mother cries. I rarely see her cry. The last time was when my grandfather died.

Then an angel arrives.

A family friend approaches mum. "Your daughter looks unwell. She is losing her hair. What is the matter?" My mother, at her wits end, tells the woman the truth. "George," the angel says. "Tell her to go to George."

George is a small town in South Africa. I learn there is a clinic that specializes in treating severe skin disease. I adamantly refuse. I have had enough of doctors, hospitals, foul smelling topical creams and hopes dashed. Mum convinces me.

In a week, I find myself there against my wishes. I withstand the indignity, once again, of being naked, the grotesque lesions under neon light, and I listen to the shocked gasps of the doctors and nurses.

"We've never seen it this bad," one says in the tiny examination room.

I glance dully outside the window of my room to see a blue lake and a blue sky amid green trees and grass. Postcard perfect. I count the hours.

Who could imagine where I am? I am a celebrity in Nairobi, making it big.

"What do you do?" I am asked.

"Nothing," I respond curtly to any one who dares make conversation with me. I certainly don't want to start a conversation about being on television or hosting a radio show for that matter. What would my viewers on KTN and listeners on Capital FM Radio think of me?

Mind, body and spirit are the focus at this clinic. It sounds insane to me. I am told to do mediation, deep relaxation and creative visualization three times a day. I lie on the floor listening to the voice in charge.

"Every day in every way I am getting better and better. I have no desire to eat the foods I know are bad for me..." I brainwash myself. It works.

I eat yogurt or bran for breakfast, salads or fish for lunch and chicken for dinner. Nothing tastes good. I yearn for Tabasco. I drink only herbal tea and torrents of water.

I berate and belittle it. I coax and cajole it. I remind it of my sexless life. I beg and plead for it to go away. Then I thank my psoriasis. It has taught me to have no vanity, more compassion and to withhold judgment.

I am crying, emotionally drained, and hot underneath my long sleeves and jeans. I take a shovel, pick a spot outside and dig deep. I place the pages into the hole. I plant a tree. I use my hands to touch the earth. Nature seems surprisingly reassuring.

In this instance, I bury my past. I have said everything I needed to say to my skin. The tree will give life, oxygen. Perhaps it will give me a chance to breathe again.

“Sonofabitch!” I yell, scaring a tiny freshman that happened to be walking right by me.

“Sorry! I wasn’t talking about you! I’m sure your mom is very pleasant!” I call after them but they’ve already scampered down the hall, probably to the safety of the freshman hall.

Someone in the office must be playing around with me, because they paired me up with the smartest and most science obsessed kid in the entire school. I was just looking for a nerd that I could charm with a smile and a low-cut top here in there to give me all the answers to my next Chem test.

JP Carlson was definitely NOT going to be that person for me. Although I had never really talked to JP, he has a reputation of being a pompous know-it-all that was also positively incorruptible . Apparently, one conversation with him will leave you feeling like a stupid monkey that hasn’t been blessed by evolution—his words, not mine. This kid would take one look at my Chemistry grade and laugh me all the way to summer school—or worse a 5th year of high school. I quickly turned back to the office and marched to the front desk.

“Excuse me,” I said to the girl sitting at the desk, “I think there has been some kind of mistake.” I handed her my paper and she glanced it over. “There is no mistake,” she said and returned my paper, “JP is the tutor that covers all junior science cases.” Cases? What the hell? I’m not a junkie or something! I’m just a dummy that can’t grasp the fundamentals of Chemistry! “Um…ok then. Sorry.” I replied, took my paper, and left the office. Guess I really am going to have to be humiliated in front of the smartest kid in all South Carolina.

I warily made my way to the library secretly hoping JP was too busy working on the next nuclear reactor or some shit to bother tutoring me.

No such luck.

He was sitting at one of the round tables near the windows with piles of chemistry books surrounding him, looking at the books like they were Lego’s and he was a three-year old kid that couldn’t wait to play with them.

“What…a…WEIRDO” I muttered and plastered a fake smile on my face as I walked up to him.

“Hi JP, I’m Charlie.”

He looked up at me and flashed the most beautiful smile I have ever seen on any human being that isn’t Ryan Gosling. I looked at him closely then realized that Mr. Supernerd is actually a Superhottie!

“Hi Charlie,” he said, the beautiful smile still on his face, “you’re ten minutes late.” Needles to say that winning smile disappeared in a heart beat and it was kind of sad to see if go.

He motioned to the seat next to him and I plopped down rolling my eyes. I was tempted tell him I didn’t want him to tutor me and was desperately trying to get rid of him, but decided against it. It’s bad enough that the nerd/hottie has to help me with chemistry and that he thinks I don’t have the mental capacity to tell time. No point adding, ‘rude bitch’ to the laundry list of my apparent flaws.

“So why are you here Charlie?” he asked after I finally pulled all my stuff from my bag.

Is this kid serious? I clearly need help in Chemistry.

“Well…um…I suck at Chemistry and would really prefer to graduate with the rest of the kids my age. So I need help,” I said trying to hide the irritation in my voice.

“Well that’s excellent!” He exclaimed adjusting his glasses (which totally hid these gorgeous grey eyes), “You are motivated and willing to take the initiative to improve your grade and your study skills.” I stared at him in disbelief.

Seriously kid, who are you? Motivation? Initiative? You sound like one of those inspirational posters they hang in the counseling office.

“Yea sure whatever,” I said tapping my pencil anxiously, “Can we get started? I have to meet up with my friends in an hour.”

“Friends can wait, Charlie. However, your performance in your chemistry class cannot afford to be ignored any longer. This tutoring session cannot wait.” JP said quietly.

Ok, I don’t care how hot this kid might be, he is really getting on my nerves. So I decided to get back at him at bit.

“JP, lemme ask you something.”

“Yes?” he asked, probably assuming I was going to ask him about photosynthesis or some sciencey shit like that.

“What do you do for fun? Like real fun, besides building models of atoms or stuff like that?” I asked.

“That question is irrelevant to this study session. If you want to ask me something about chemistry then I have an answer for you.” He retorted.

“It was just a simple question” I muttered flipping through my chemistry book—it looked like gibberish to me.

“Ok,” he said, “Well I have a simple question for you.”

“Go ahead. I’m an open book. Pun intended” I replied glibly, motioning to the open book in front of me.

I could tell he wanted to laugh at my cheesy joke but decided to say “professional”

“Why are you really here? I looked at you transcript and chemistry is not the only class you are struggling in. You’ve pulled up your other grades from earlier this semester, but something doesn’t make sense. You were a fairly good student before Christmas break and all of a sudden your grades plummet. What happened over Christmas break?” he asked.

Oh I don’t know…lets think. Well first I lied to my best friends, nearly got them arrested and all of that just to lose the love of my life to my childhood arch nemesis. Nope…nothing of significance that would cause my grades to fall. But there is no way in hell I’m telling Mr. Smarty Pants all that though.

“Look, it’s really cute that you care and everything,” I said slamming my book closed and standing up, “But I did not sign up for a counseling session. So if you want to go all Oprah circa 2004 on me, I can leave.”

“Charlie sit down,” JP said, standing up as well. “I didn’t mean to upset you. You obviously don’t want to talk about it so let’s just keep this professional and leave the personal questions outside of the tutoring sessions? OK?”

Outside of tutoring sessions? Does he think we’re going to become besties and talk about our life problems? I think not.

“Fine…”I muttered. “But the only reason I’m staying is because being on the five-year plan is really not a good look for anyone.”
